title: The Program
description: To begin your journey as a C++ adventurer, you must prepare your environment and cast your very first spell ‚Äî a simple message that echoes through the console realm.
task: Write a C++ program that prints 'Hello, C++!' to the console.

title: Hello World
description: Learn the basic C++ syntax for printing text using cout.
task: Complete the cout statement so it prints 'Hello World!' to the console.
hints: Use << endl to end the line.

title: Comments
description: Comments can be used to explain C++ code, and to make it more readable. It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code. Comments can be singled-lined or multi-lined.
task: Add a comment above the code that prints 'Code runs!' to the console.
startingCode:
// Write your comment here
cout << "" << endl;
hints: Comments are ignored by the compiler.

title: Basic Output
description: you can Print numbers and text to the console.
task: Print a triangle pattern using asterisks (*) with three rows.
hints: Each row should be printed on a new line.

title: Variables
description: In C++, a variable is a name given to a memory location. It is the basic unit of storage in a program. The value stored in a variable can be accessed or changed during program execution.
task: Declare the two integer variable named 'age' and 'year' and assign it with a value, then print the output of each variable.

title: Basic Data Types
description: Understand int, float, , string, double, char, and bool.
task: Declare a double variable 'price' with value 9.99 and a bool variable 'isStudent' with value true, then print both.

title: Constants
description: The const keyword (which stands for constant) is used to specify that the value of a variable cannot be changed anywhere in the program, either intentionally or accidentally.
lessonExample:
const int DAYS_IN_WEEK = 7;
cout << DAYS_IN_WEEK << endl;
task: Declare a constant integer 'DAYS_IN_WEEK' with value 7 and print it.
startingCode:
const int DAYS_IN_WEEK = ;
cout << DAYS_IN_WEEK << endl;

title: Type Casting
description: Converting the value of one type to another type is also known as type casting.
task: Cast the double value 9.7 to an integer and print the result.

title: Arithmetic Operators
description: Use +, -, *, /, and % to perform arithmetic operations.
task: Using integer variables a and b with values 7 and 2, calculate a + b and print the result to the console.
hints: You can print text and values together using cout.

title: Comparison Operators
lessonExample:
int a = 5, b = 3;
cout << (a > b) << endl;
task: Compare two integers 5 and 3 using > operator and print the result.
hints: cout prints 1 for true, 0 for false.

title: Logical Operators
task: Use logical AND (&&) to combine two boolean values true and false, then print the result.
lessonExample:
bool a = true, b = false;
cout << (a && b) << endl;
hints: Use && for AND, || for OR, ! for NOT.
cout prints 1 for true, 0 for false.

title: Assignment Operators
description: Use =, +=, -=, *=, /= to assign and update values.
task: Use the += operator to add 3 to the variable a initialized to 5, then print the result.

title: If Statements
description: Control program flow using if statements.
task: Check if the variable 'age' (set to 18) is greater than or equal to 18, and print 'Adult' if true.

title: Switch Case
description: Use switch to select one of many code paths.
task: Use a switch statement to print 'Tue' when the variable 'day' is set to 2.

title: For Loops
task: Use a for loop to print numbers 0 to 2.
lessonExample: for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) cout << i << endl;
startingCode: for (int i = 0; i < ; i++) cout << i << endl;

title: While Loops
description: Repeat actions while a condition is true.
task: Use a while loop to print numbers 0 to 2.

title: C++ Exam
description: Test your C++ knowledge covering all modules.
task: Write a C++ program that defines a function to add two integers and prints the result of adding 5 and 7.
hints: Use variables, loops, conditionals, and functions.
